results.title: Paddle Steamer Curlip
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Join a group of passionate volunteers as they describe the trials, tribulations and joys of building and running a paddle steamer. From the initial planning in 2002, a group of Orbost locals built the PS Curlip II as part of a community project. After 16,000 hours of voluntary labour the paddle steamer was launched and continues in 2013 to transport tourists in and around the various waterways of East Gippsland. Members of the PS Curlip Committee talk about the history, their involvement and the future of the much-loved paddle steamer.

results.title: Orbost Locals
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Learn about the town of Orbost through a diverse range of locals as they talk about why they love their town, their community and the surrounding environment. Meet Mick Colling, the publican of the Orbost Club Hotel, who is heavily involved in fundraising within his local community and in particular for Ronald McDonald House. Lachie Macalister, a ‘true’ local and over eighty years old, has lived and farmed in Orbost all his life, growing everything from potatoes to pumpkins and working the land with pigs and cattle. Heather Terrell is many things: a passionate gardener, volunteer and member of the local historical society. Liz Mitchell, a tree changer and small business owner who decided to move to Orbost because she loved the environment and wanted to raise her family in a rural region. Finally, there’s Sam Mitchell, an 18-year-old student known around town for the extraordinary machines he builds and rides.

results.title: My Omeo: A Short History
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jeff Cooper is a guardian of all things great about Omeo and its chequered history. His role within the community is not only as a custodian of the local records but also as a passionate tour guide of the Omeo Historic Park and local gold fields. The Park contains 5 heritage-listed buildings that are believed to be some of the most intact and original in Australia. Jeff believes Omeo is the last bastion of self-funded retirement and despite losing his home and livestock in the 2003 bushfires, wouldn’t live anywhere else in the world.

results.title: Lakes Entrance Surf Life Saving Club
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Members of the Lakes Entrance Life Saving Club discuss why the club plays such an important role within their lives and their community. Founded in 1956, the Lakes Entrance Surf Life Saving Club in 2013 has over 400 members and patrols the beach from November through to Easter. The Club not only provides a vital service to locals and tourists alike, but is also a fantastic way for the young people of Lake’s Entrance to gain life skills, practical knowledge and build confidence.

results.title: Lakes Entrance Fishing
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: A story about a fishing family and the importance of the fishing industry within the town of Lakes Entrance. Arthur Allen and his family have maintained a tradition of lake fishing in East Gippsland for five generations and hope to continue for many years to come. Despite the uncertainty of the industry, Arthur, his son Matthew and the Lakes Entrance Fishermen’s Co-op, strive to keep fishing alive in Lakes Entrance.

results.title: Deirdre Jack: Swifts Creek Artist
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Local painter, Deirdre Jack, is passionate about her local environment. The rolling hills and golden fields that surround her Swifts Creek bush studio inevitably make their way into her vibrant oil paintings and pastel sketches. Fruit, however, is the main subject of her exhibition at the Great Alpine Gallery, a small exhibition space that sits in the heart of Swifts Creek and run voluntarily by a group of fellow artists. The gallery has been a vital place for local artists since 1989 despite the challenges of running an art space in a small rural town.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Wangaratta
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: This program contains nine stories about residents from around the Wangaratta region in north-eastern Victoria. Covering the towns of Eldorado, King Valley, Greta, Whitfield and Whitlands, locals tell stories about their lives and their connection to the land and the community.

results.title: The Whitlands Plateau
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Distance is no barrier to this active group of entrepreneurs who have a rich history and a strong community spirit. From lawyers and artists to viticulturists and wine makers, the small plateau in Whitlands, in north-eastern Victoria, attracts a diverse group of talented and hard working professionals. We meet some life-long locals and a newcomer to town and hear about the history of the area as well as the ventures that are being undertaken in 2012 Whitlands.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Pizzini Family
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: This is a story about an Italian-Australian family made unique by three generations of winemakers and master chefs. Meet Natalie, Alfred, Arnold, Katrina, Carla and matriarch Rosetta Pizzini, hear about the four brothers that immigrated to Australia and started farming tobacco, eventually diversifying to growing Italian variety grapes. The Pizzini’s make their own wine, run a cooking school and manage a boutique hotel in Whitfield, but still the most important part of their day is when they sit together and share a meal, a glass of wine and a laugh.

results.title: The Greta Swamp
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
